Introduction

A hydrocele is a collection of fluid within the tunica vaginalis, which can lead to scrotal swelling.  Most cases are congenital and occur in neonates; acquired cases typically occur in older children and adolescents and are often secondary to injury, infection, or tumors.

Pathogenesis and risk factors

A hydrocele forms due to an imbalance between the secretion and reabsorption of fluid by the tunica vaginalis (

figure 1
).  It can occur congenitally or can be acquired secondarily.

Congenital hydrocele

During embryogenesis, the testis descends through the inguinal canal, drawing with it a diverticulum of peritoneum into the scrotum.  This peritoneal tissue is known as the processus vaginalis.  Normally, communication between the processus vaginalis and the peritoneum is obliterated, and the tunica vaginalis is the remaining tissue overlying the testis and epididymis.

  • A congenital communicating hydrocele results when the processus vaginalis remains patent and allows peritoneal fluid to accumulate in the tunica vaginalis.
  • A noncommunicating hydrocele is formed if the processus obliterates normally but fluid collected within the tunica vaginalis does not reabsorb.

Acquired hydrocele

In an acquired hydrocele, the fluid accumulation is often a reactive response that occurs secondary to trauma, infection, lymphatic obstruction, or malignancy.  However, idiopathic cases can occur.

Clinical presentation

Both congenital and acquired cases of hydrocele present as painless enlargement of the scrotum.  On examination, it is distinct from the adjacent testis and epididymis but overlies those structures and may partially or completely obscure palpation of scrotal contents.

In infants with a communicating hydrocele, the swelling may fluctuate with crying or straining (increased intraabdominal pressure); however, a noncommunicating hydrocele is irreducible and remains constant in size.

In older adolescents, a large hydrocele may also cause a "heaviness" or discomfort in the scrotum that causes pain or discomfort during physical activity or sexual intercourse.

Differential diagnosis

  • Inguinal hernia:  usually presents with a visible groin bulge that may extend into the scrotum and worsens with Valsalva maneuver (eg, coughing); however, the intestinal contents do not allow for transillumination during examination
  • Varicocele:  presents as a soft, irregular structure (ie, "bag of worms") in the scrotum that is more pronounced with standing (due to venous pooling with gravity).
  • Testicular tumor:  can cause a hydrocele; however, patients often also have a firm, painless mass within the testicle that is not transilluminable.
  • Epididymitis/orchitis:  can cause a reactive, acquired hydrocele; however, patients have painful scrotal swelling and additional symptoms (eg, dysuria, urethral discharge).

Diagnosis, laboratory evaluation, and imaging studies

The diagnosis of a hydrocele is primarily clinical, particularly in cases of congenital hydrocele.

On examination, a smooth, soft, fluctuant mass separate from the testicle is often palpable.  On penlight examination, the mass transilluminates (positive transillumination test), in which the mass allows light to pass through, indicating a fluid-filled cavity.

Scrotal ultrasonography can confirm the diagnosis and enable visualization of the underlying testis for possible malignancy (

image 1
).  On ultrasound examination, a hydrocele appears as a uniform fluid collection without vascularity, lying anterior (superficial) to the testis.

In cases of acquired hydrocele, urinalysis and tumor markers (eg, alpha-fetoprotein, hCG) are often ordered to rule out secondary causes, such as epididymitis and testicular tumors.

Management and prognosis

Most cases of congenital hydrocele resolve spontaneously within the first year of life and may be observed unless symptomatic or persistent beyond 2 years.  If the hydrocele persists or becomes symptomatic, surgical intervention (eg, aspiration, excising the tunica vaginalis) is indicated.

Summary

A hydrocele is a collection of fluid within the tunica vaginalis.  Most cases are congenital and occur in neonates; acquired cases typically occur in older children and adolescents and are often secondary to injury, infection, or tumors.  A hydrocele usually resolves spontaneously, typically by age 2 in congenital cases and after treating the underlying cause in acquired cases.
